resources.string:
Objective:
 The objective of Sudoku is to fill a 9x9 grid with numbers so that each column, each row, and each of the nine 3x3 subgrids (also known as regions or blocks) contain all of the digits from 1 to 9. The puzzle starts with some cells pre-filled with numbers, and the player must fill in the remaining cells following the rules.
 
 Rules:
 Grid:
 The Sudoku grid consists of a 9x9 square divided into nine 3x3 subgrids.
 Each row, column, and subgrid must contain the numbers 1 through 9, with no repetition.
 Numbers:
 Fill in the grid with numbers from 1 to 9.
 Each row must contain all the numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition.
 Each column must contain all the numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition.
 Each 3x3 subgrid must contain all the numbers from 1 to 9 with no repetition.
 Starting Numbers:
 At the beginning of the game, some cells in the grid are pre-filled with numbers.
 These starting numbers serve as clues and cannot be changed.
 Empty Cells:
 The remaining cells that are not pre-filled must be filled by the player.
 Each empty cell must be filled with a number from 1 to 9 following the rules.
 Logic and Deduction:
 Sudoku is a game of logic and deduction. There should be only one solution for a well-formed Sudoku puzzle.
 Players use deductive reasoning to determine the correct numbers for each cell based on the given clues and the numbers already placed on the board.
 Completion:
 The puzzle is solved when all empty cells are filled, and the numbers meet the rules for rows, columns, and subgrids.
 
 Tips:
 Start with the easiest numbers and work your way to the more challenging ones.
 Use the process of elimination to figure out which numbers can go in a particular cell.
 Pay attention to the interactions between rows, columns, and subgrids to make logical decisions.
 Enjoy the challenge of solving Sudoku puzzles!
